questions.text: A Nursing assistant posted in obstetric care was asked to plot a partograph to monitor the progress of labour. After how much dilatation of the cervix, must she start plotting the graph?
questions.solution:
Partogram is the graphical recording of stages of labour including cervical dilatation, descent and rotation of the head.

  • It was introduced by WHO a part of the Safe Motherhood initiative.
  • The main purposeof the partogram is to avoid prolonged labour and intervene timely.
  • Once labour is diagnosed, its progress is charted on a partogram by abdominal and vaginal examination
  • The latent phase of labour is up to 3 cm dilatation, and should not be more than 8 In the active phase which extends from 3 cm to complete cervical dilatation, labour is expected to progress at the rate of at least 1 cm cervical dilatation per hour which corresponds to the alert line.
  • The action line is drawn 4 hours to the right and parallel to the alert line in the WHO partogram.
  • Labour is considered normal as long as the progress of cervical dilatation is to the left of the alert line.
  • Prolonged labour is diagnosed, once the alert line is crossed, e., there is a shift to the right. This is considered an indication for intervention.
  • If the patient is in a peripheral hospital, once the alert line is crossed, it is an indication for referral to a higher center.
  • If action line is crossed, it is an inducation for cesarean section.

Thus, the partogram can be used to identify an abnormal labour pattern and to indicate the correct time for intervention by means of the alert and action lines.

How to use it -

A partograph must be started only when a woman is in labor.

The partograph is used to plot the following parameters for the progress of labor:

  1. cervical dilatation,
  2. descent of fetal head, and
  3. uterine contractions. It will also be used for monitoring fetal conditions with the following parameters: fetal heart rate, membranes and liquor and moulding of fetal skull. Additionally, the partograph can be used to monitor maternal condition:

Cervical dilatation: The rate of dilatation of the cervix changes during labor, this is represented by the bold lines in the graph.

Dilatation of the cervix is measured by the diameter in cm. This is recorded with an X in the center of the partograph, at the intersection of vertical and horizontal lines. The vertical scale represents dilatation by 10 squares of 1 cm each. The horizontal scale represents time by 24 squares of one hour each.

questions.text: Identify the fetal presentation
questions.solution: Here, the occiput is directed towards right thigh and hence it is a ROP position.

questions.text: Which virus has following pathophysiology and causes microcephaly in fetus?
questions.solution:
Zika virus infection during pregnancy can cause infants to be born with microcephaly and other congenital malformations as well as preterm birth and miscarriage. Zika virus infection is associated with Guillain- Barré syndrome, neuropathy and myelitis in adults and children. Zika infection during pregnancy causes a birth defect called microcephaly and other brain problems. It also may be linked to other serious problems for a baby.

B. Rubella Virus (German Measles)

  • Teratogenic Effects: Rubella is highly teratogenic and can cause Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS), which includes:
    • Heart Defects: Patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary artery stenosis.
    • Eye Abnormalities: Cataracts, retinopathy, and glaucoma.
    • Hearing Loss: Often the most common defect.
    • Neurodevelopmental Defects: Intellectual disabilities, microcephaly, and behavioral disorders.
    • Others: Hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, growth retardation.
  • Highest Risk Period: Infection during the first 12 weeks is associated with the highest risk of severe congenital defects. Risk decreases but persists in the second trimester.

C. Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

  • Teratogenic Effects: CMV is the most common congenital viral infection and can lead to:
    • Sensorineural Hearing Loss: Often progressive and bilateral.
    • Neurodevelopmental Issues: Intellectual disability, microcephaly, and seizures.
    • Vision Problems: Chorioretinitis, optic nerve atrophy.
    • Growth Restriction: Low birth weight and small for gestational age.
    • Hepatosplenomegaly, Thrombocytopenia, Jaundice: Symptoms that may indicate congenital CMV at birth.
  • Highest Risk Period: Primary maternal CMV infection in the first and second trimesters poses the highest risk for fetal abnormalities. Recurrent infections tend to be less severe.

D. Parvovirus B19

  • Teratogenic Effects: Parvovirus B19 primarily affects fetal red blood cells, which can lead to:
    • Fetal Anemia: Can be severe and lead to hydrops fetalis, a potentially fatal condition marked by fluid accumulation in fetal compartments.
    • Heart Failure: Due to the anemia-induced increased cardiac workload.
    • Miscarriage and Stillbirth: High risk, particularly with infection during the first 20 weeks.
  • Highest Risk Period: Infection during the first half of pregnancy poses the highest risk of adverse effects; later infections may still cause complications but with reduced risk.

questions.solution:
Robson classification is a 10 point classification given by WHO and used by various institutes to compare the rates of Cesarean section and its indications. 5 parameters used are:

  • Parity
  • Gestational age
  • Presentation
  • Number of fetus
  • Spontaneous labour/ Induced labour

Reference: https://www.who.int/publications-detail-redirect/9789241513197

Flex knee and dorsiflex the foot
Extend knee and plantar flex the foot
Flex knee and plantar flex the foot

questions.text: A pregnant female has cramps in her legs. What will you suggest to relieve the pain?
questions.solution:
Why do pregnant ladies get leg cramps?

It may have to do with changes in blood circulation and stress on your leg muscles from carrying extra weight. Your growing baby also puts pressure on the nerves and blood vessels that go to your legs. And some doctors say low calcium, or a change in the way your body processes calcium, may cause cramps

If you get a leg cramp, stretch the calf muscle. Walking and then sitting and raising your legs might help keep the leg cramp from coming back. A hot shower, warm bath, ice massage or muscle massage may help too.

Reference: https://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-lifestyle/pregnancy-week-by-week/expert-answers/leg-cramps-during-pregnancy/faq-20057766#:~:text=Leg%20cramps%20are%20painful%20muscle,take%20steps%20to%20prevent%20them.

choices.text: Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery
Breech delivery is done only in a hospital where a facility for Emergency CS is available
Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labour
Performed only with help of experienced senior obstetrician

questions.text: A lady presented for vaginal breech delivery. Which among the following is false?
questions.solution:
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists makes the following recommendations:

  • The decision regarding the mode of delivery should consider patient wishes and the experience of the health care provider.
  • Obstetrician-gynecologists and other obstetric care providers should offer external cephalic version as an alternative to planned cesarean for a woman who has a term singleton breech fetus, desires a planned vaginal delivery of a vertex-presenting fetus and has no contraindications. External cephalic version should be attempted only in settings in which cesarean delivery services are readily available.
  • Planned vaginal delivery of a term singleton breech fetus may be reasonable under hospital-specific protocol guidelines for eligibility and labor management.
  • If a vaginal breech delivery is planned, a detailed informed consent should be documented-including risks that perinatal or neonatal mortality or short-term serious neonatal morbidity may be higher than if a cesarean delivery is planned
  • Options B,C,D are correct

questions.text: Recombinant HPV Vaccine is made from?
questions.solution:
Currently, three HPV vaccines are FDA approved for prevention of incident HPV infection and cervical neoplasia.

They use recombinant technologies for the synthetic production of the L1 capsid proteins of each HPV type included in the vaccine.

The resultant virus-like particles are highly immunogenic but are not infectious as they lack viral DNA.

Cervarix (HPV2) is a bivalent vaccine against HPVs 16 and 18.

Gardasil (HPV4) is a quadrivalent vaccine against HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18.

HPV4 is being replaced by Gardasil 9 (HPV9), a nonavalent vaccine. HPV9 protects against all HPV types in HPV4 plus types 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas infection

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient with repeated infections of trichomonas vaginitis is adviced for pap smear by her gynecologist. She questions you, the intern, regarding the purpose of this test. What would be your response?
questions.solution:
Pap smear is the primary and widely used screening test for Cervical CA.

Pap Smear(Exfoliative Cytology)

  • Time for initiating pap smear: 21 years of age regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
    • Instrument used: Ayres spatula and endocervical brush
    • Method: Ayres spatula is rotated through 360° over portio vaginalis of cervix and 1st slide is prepared
  • With cytobrush, 2nd slide is prepared from endocervix
  • Control slide prepared from posterior wall/posterior fornix of vagina
    • Fixative used: 95% ethyl alcohol and

Note: Liquid base cytology is being used now a days. Preservative used in liquid based cytology is Methanol.

If liquid based cytology is being done it should be repeated every 2 years till female is 30 years of age then 3 years

Option B: Saline microscopy is the IOC for genital infections like Trichomoniasis

Option C: Pap smear is a screening test. Diagnostic methods are radiological and histopathological methods

Option D: Genital infections can be diagnosed by saline microscopy

choices.text: Gently Replace the cord inside the vagina
Inform doctor and shift to OT
Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.text: A midwife is examining a pregnant woman in labour when she noticed cord prolapse. What is the next immediate step of management that she should do?
questions.solution:
This is a case of cord prolapse and putting her in Trendelenburg position and attempting to lift the presenting part is the best step.

  1. This is the most fatal step and hence avoided
  2. It takes time and by that time fetus may be harmed
  3. No need of this
